author: Kasra Moradi
title: Justin Thomas 'luck' stuns Rory McIlroy, Donald Trump's $175M problem - NewsBreak
text: Golf enthusiasts have been on the edge of their seats this week with a series of thrilling events shaking up the sport. The excitement peaked when Rory McIlroy clinched his second victory at The Players Championship , outplaying J.J. Spaun in a nail-biting three-hole playoff that extended the tournament to a fifth day at TPC Sawgrass. The golf world was left stunned by Justin Thomas' incredible stroke of luck during the TGL Finals Series' second semifinal on Tuesday. Thomas led his team, Atlanta Drive Golf Club, to a commanding 9-3 win against Shane Lowry's Bay Golf Club, setting the stage for an epic final against Xander Schauffele's New York squad next week. Thomas' good fortune came into play halfway through the match, as Atlanta held a 4-2 lead. His iron shot on the par-five 10th took a miraculous bounce, steering clear of a hazard and setting him up for a two-putt par that helped him secure a win over Lowry. TGL co-founder McIlroy couldn't hide his astonishment at Thomas' lucky break, exclaiming "no" and adding on commentary: "I don't want to sound biased here but that is just the luckiest bounce I've ever seen." This came after McIlroy's own Boston Common team was eliminated from the playoffs following a 10-6 defeat by New York. Looking ahead, McIlroy is gearing up for his next challenge at the Texas Children's Houston Open. Fresh off his triumph at The Players, he announced his intention to compete once more before making his way to Augusta, aiming to snap his prolonged major title drought. The World No. 2 has now decided to participate in The Houston Open for the first time, which tees off on Thursday, March 27. This gives McIlroy a week's rest before he sets his sights on his first green jacket. In other news, Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) is reportedly poised to throw a wrench into discussions aimed at resolving golf's internal conflict. The backers of LIV Golf have been in talks with the rival PGA Tour about a possible merger, having held two meetings at the White House with United States President Donald Trump. However, these promising discussions could be in jeopardy following a report by the Daily Mail this week that the PIF is stepping up its efforts to acquire Wentworth Golf Club in England. Hosting the DP World Tour's flagship BMW PGA Championship each year, a takeover by LIV would likely ruffle feathers among both the formerly named European Tour and their allies, the PGA Tour. According to the report, Wentworth's current owners, Chinese investment firm Reignwood Group, told the Daily Mail that the Surrey-based club they bought for Â£135 million ($175.5 million) in 2014 is not on the market, and no discussions have taken place with the Saudis. Despite this, the PIF is keen to expand its footprint in British golf, which could put a damper on the initial optimism surrounding Trump's involvement in the merger talks. Adam Scott, a member of the PGA Tour delegation that visited the White House last month, suggests that the ongoing negotiations are being hampered by disagreements over how LIV Golf and the PGA Tour can coexist. The Daily Mail's report also hinted that Saudi Arabia's interest in acquiring Wentworth might be a strategic move to pressure the PGA Tour into an agreement. The PGA Tour received a significant boost from last weekend's viewership numbers. The final round of The Players on NBC significantly outperformed the final round of LIV Golf's Singapore event on FS1, with a ratio of 100-1. McIlroy's victory over Spaun attracted an average of 3.6 million viewers on NBC, marking a roughly 3 percent increase from Scottie Scheffler's win the previous year. In contrast, LIV Golf's event, which ran from Saturday night into the early hours of Sunday, saw Joaquin Niemann's win draw a modest average of 34,000 viewers, following the Saudi-backed golf tour's new media rights deal with FOX Sports. Meanwhile, PGA Tour members are currently voting until April 14 to elect two co-chairs for the Player Advisory Council. Rickie Fowler, Maverick McNealy, and Keith Mitchell were announced as candidates on Tuesday, chosen by the player directors. The top two vote-getters will replace current player directors Peter Malnati and Webb Simpson starting January 1, 2026.
